response.answer_text: Yes actually that is also proper way to address a dentist. A dentist is both a doctor and a dentist. Who is a doctor? Someone who is qualified, to treat people who are ill,recognized and licensed. Who is a dentist? Someone who is qualified to treat illeness that affect teeth and gums,recognized and licenced. Gum is part of the body, teeth are part if body. Both are supplied by nerves,blood and nutrients. The tissues are live. Unlike nails,which are dead cells or tissues that is being exfoliated, teeth are not dead or not naturally exfoliated (except in the case of milk teeth that are near its functional life span). So what a dentist is dealing with is live body.A body part which responds just the way as any other part of body. And there are hundreds of diseases, issues affecting teeth and gums. And most or almost all are connected to the rest of the body. You simply cannot isolate the oral cavity from rest of the body. So as a dentist,one needs to learn about,specifically about many many illnesses that directly affect the teeth and gums.They study oral cavity and diseases in association with rest of the body. In effect, dentists need to know much in detail about the body as a whole. The medicine they prescribe are the same medicines that physicians use. And all about the medicine need to be understood by the dentist. A dentist need to know one hundred percentage of basic stuff that the physician learns,plus all the specific stuff. My own thought,as a dentist, about acquiring knowledge regarding human body and illness is that one needs to know as much and as deep as anyone who wants to repair the human body. I prefer to be called a Dentist, though. To me the word 'dentist' is stylish and specific to my profession.

I think dentist are never trying to search for regenerative medicine for teeth. They just keep cutting the teeth untill there are none. Here is my true story: one day while brushing I realised that one of my tooth needed attention. I was having a black spot on this tooth since childhood. It was my first visit to dentist, I was 25 age approx. During my session with the dentist she told me that not one but two of my teeth were required to have root canal. But I had never seen any defect in that upper tooth which was directly opposite to the tooth I wanted to be repaired. Non the less the doctor went on doing for both the tooth and I was sitting on the seat with Anastasiya. I was unable to take a judgement myself. Best to my surprise during the operation she used pointed knife and touched other teeth. By the end of the session, she started telling that my teeth were not well and I may need another tooth to be repaired in Next six month. I felt I never had a tooth decay ever and the only tooth that had a dark spot was from childhood. I realised and I never went back to any dentist ever. After six months the other tooth started decaying. I realised that she had cut my other teeth to expose the inner layers of the teeth so that she will get a good buisness out of me. In one year I realised that she had damaged 7 teeth I that single session. and that now I had to take extra effort to take care of these 7 teeth. After 15 years, today all of my teeth are good. Except I take very good care of those 7 teeth by brushing two times every day. Still these damaged teeyh are wearing faster but I don't need a dentist they are healthy and white.. I try. I feel if it goes this way these teeth will remain active 20 years atleast hopefully. But the wear is catching 🙁 I regret every day ,why I went to the fucking dentist who tried to rob me of my teeth. Just brush twice daily, and do regular flossing. Research on Regenerative tooth is in progress and it will make todays dentristry useless.

Umm, usually, no. In some countries in order to get a dental degree, you have to finish a medical degree and do dentistry as a specialty. However, in most Western countries, dentistry is a separate degree to medicine. Here in New Zealand, dentists are conferred the right to practice dentistry, which includes surgery to the jaws, and lower face; and we have the right of prescription of the full pharmaceutical schedule of drugs (the same as medical doctors), but must justify the use of the drugs for dental reasons. Some dentists use the title of “Dr”; and some don’t. This is an affectation of tradition passed onto dentists from when the profession of modern dentistry was in it’s infancy - way way back in the late 1700s. As a dentist, I really have no opinion on whether dentists should be called “Dr”, the fee is the same what ever they call me. I do have a preference, I prefer them to call me “Adrian”, and NOT “Dr Tan”.

Well, I am a dentist and I am called a Doctor. Why shouldn't dentists be called doctors? An MBBS graduate and a BDS graduate studies the same subjects for the first 3 years- 1.Human Anatomy 2. Human Physiology 3. Biochemistry 4. General Pathology 5. Microbiology 6. General Medicine 7. General Surgery And there are additional subjects which I've not listed which we need to study along with the above mentioned in the first 3 years. It's only in the final year that our respective field branches out. Namely- Oral and Maxillofacial SurgeryConservative & endodonticsPeriodonticsPedodonticsOral medicine and radiologyOrthodonticsCommunity dentistryProsthodonticsA BDS graduate is required to have sound knowledge of all the aspects of human body and then they are taught to deal with the oral aspect of the body, do you understand the reason for it? Oral cavity is as important as any other part of the body, it is the gateway of food, you eating your favourite food , able to taste all of the flavours is because of your tongue. Your teeth(In good condition) when you smile makes you look good. Any type of disease you have, it will show in your mouth. It all means one thing, oral cavity is so important and vast that they decided to make it another branch altogether. So, yes, I think that we should be called doctors. We are rightfully called doctors. Hope this helps.

In the past the dentist was a barber, a surgeon-charlatan.  Today, it is not actually a medical doctor (legal title) because he does not study “medicine and surgery”. He is a dental doctor and dental surgeon ! (a different legal title, intended for dental and oral diseases professionals) The profession is concerned with the prevention and treatment of oral disease, including diseases of the teeth and supporting structures and diseases of the soft tissues of the mouth. [1]  Today, a dentist is charged with : assesing a dental patient with extraoral and intraoral examinationassing a dental patient with pre-exisiting medical condition that might affect dental treatment. So he need to study a little bit of general medicine as well. But he cannot make a systemic medical diagnosis! Here the important concept of referral to medical specialists or family medical doctors.Footnotes[1] dentistry

“Are dentists physicians.” In the U.S. medical and dental education diverges after undergraduate work is completed, although dentists and physicians end up being Doctor. Both are licensed and qualified to do surgical and other procedures as well as prescribing medications. Physician is defined as a person qualified to practice medicine, dentist is defined as a person qualified to treat the diseases and conditions that affect the teeth and gums, especially the repair and extraction of teeth and the insertion of artificial ones. So a dentist is not a physician, at least in the U.S. In Europe, if you want to be a dentist, you complete a medical education first, then specialize in dentistry. In this case a dentist is a physician.

No. They are dentists and this usually because they could not get into Medical School. Physicians really know nothing about the mouth and Dentists know very little about what happens outside of the mouth. I worked the Emergency Room many times on weekend nights knowing nothing about dentistry. Yet, I was counted on more often than not to help patients with bad teeth in order to alleviate their suffering. We were allowed to do nothing more than prescribe some sort of pain relief and wait for a dentist to help these patients or face malpractice claims!

Sure, but why would anyone want to do this? It’s like going to medical/dental school twice. I did run across an excellent oral and Maxillofacial surgeon (a field within dentistry) that was also a doctor of pharmacy. Man was he good with anesthetic and pain control! I’ve also run across dentists that were attorneys, in which case their decision to return to school was driven by necessity, due to physical injuries that ended their dental career.  The foregoing is informational only and is not intended to be medical advice. The California Dental Practice Act prohibits hygienists from diagnosing disease and/or recommending definitive treatment. Cathye L. Smithwick, RDH, MA Silicon Valley Dental Hygienist Author: Dental Benefits, a Guide to Managed Plans

No, dentists are dentists. They usually have the same medical school education as medical students for two or more years. Thereafter, they part ways. That being said, in Norway they are medical specialists known as gnathostomatologists. Many oral surgeons are double degree dentists with a DDS an MD. There was only one doctor who became a dentist later, Emmanuel Cheraskin, MD, DDS who was the dean of the Alabama University Medical School at the time. His education was abbreviated, as he had all of the medical portions under his belt. He was a quick study and completed all of the clinical requirements.

A college teacher and a school teacher are both teachers right? Just for different subjects and levels. Central govt ministers and state govt ministers are both called Ministers, they just work on different platforms. And for your kind information when it would pain in the tooth or there might be a jaw fracture or abnormal bleeding from gums or displacement of mandible or carcinoma of tongue, palate, other oral structures or a wisdom tooth might be making the life hell.. None of the “doctors whom you could actually call doctors” will be able to help you. The last resort would be a Dentist and while in excruciating pain only one word would come out of the mouth to refer him or her by- *DOCTOR*

Here’s the way my Dentist, who actually taught Dentistry at the local very highly rated Medical College of VA explained it to me. “We go through all the pre-med courses but then move into Dentistry and our focus becomes the teeth, now with that said the mouth is a cavern of evidence of heart disease, infections, all sorts of problems from the body. So yes in a way we are Physicians but we then refer the patient to their regular Dr. for follow-up.”

Yes and they often do. The first two years of dental school and medical school are equal in most respects except the course load is heavier for the dental student. Many, perhaps most, Oral Maxillofacial Surgeons have dual degrees: DDS (or DMD) and MD. When I practiced in Pasadena, the dentist next door went to medical school and ultimately became a plastic surgeon. A classmate of mine went into an anesthesia residency program following dental school and also achieved a dual degree, DDS and MD. Another classmate earned the DDS degree then he went into an oral surgery program. When he left that program he had earned his MD degree. Then he went to law school and earned the JD degree. He also married and had 7 children. There is no limit for motivated people with brains.

Yes. Dentist’s earn the degree of Doctor of Dental Surgery ( DDS ) or Doctor of Medical Dentistry ( DMD) after successfully completing 4 years of predental studies and earning a Bachelor of Science (BS) or Bachelor of Arts (BA) degree at a 4 year university or college and the completing 4 years of post graduate studies at an accredited dental school. After those 8 years most dental school graduates complete a 1 or 2 year general practice residency at a hospital or conti hue their education for another 3 to 4 years to specialize in one of the 6 reggnized dental specialties, including orthodontics, oral surgery, endodontics, periodontics, Pedodontist or prosthodontics.

No. A Dentist holds a Doctor of Dentistry and is known as a DD. A Medical Doctor holds a Doctor of Medicine and is known as an MD. You would not want your DD treating you for the flu or setting a broken arm. Likewise, you would not want an MD to drill your teeth or fit a crown. Different training, different degrees, different skill sets.

Dentists are a very specialized type of doctor who deal only with dental-oral conditions. Your dentist should be addressed as doctor if he/she has the title DDS (Doctor of Dental Surgery) or DMD (Doctor of Medicine in Dentistry) behind his or her name. However, when speaking about your dentist, you should say dentist to differentiate this doctor from your family physician, who's often referred to as your doctor. Hope this helps.

Hi there. Yes, dentists are doctors. They diagnose and treat diseases of the oral cavity and head and neck. Dentists perform various surgeries as well. In fact the degree of BDS itself stands for bachelor of dental surgery. As for whether they are medical doctors, the subjects studied are all medicine based. The initial three years are spent studying the concepts of basic medical sciences. However as dentists, we are confined to the head and neck and not the diseases of the rest of the body. Hope this answers your question.

In North America, dental colleges award two named degrees: DDS, Doctor of Dental SurgeryDMD, Doctor of Medical DentistryThese designation are not “doctors” with the same meaning as medical doctor (MD). A number of dentists also go to medical school and earn an MD. Many dual-degreed dentists then practice oral & maxillofacial surgery.

A doctor is someone who treats your body. Mouth obviously is a part of your body and a dentist treats it. Its a specialisation in a body part. Just because it is done in separate degree, it doesn't become any less important. Every Dentist is a Doctor, but every Doctor is not a Dentist.

Can I ask why are homeopaths and Ayurveds are considered as doctor? We dentist study more than 80 percent of MBBS subjects in addition complete course of dentistry. We have complete knowledge of anatomy physiology pharmacology pathology and many other vital subjects.. once this my MBBS friend has told that dentist are way superior than any other doctors because dentists are doctors and they are specialized in a branch which deals with maxillofacial structures..

Depends on how you define 'medical doctor' per se. In many education systems, like that of India, dentists study a different course than 'medical doctors'. While I would define a medical doctor as someone who has done an MBBS for graduation, a dentist is one who does a BDS (bachelor of dental surgery) for grad. Dentists are trained to treat clinical disorders and medical conditions more or less limited to the oral cavity and surrounding structures.

Of course we're allowed to, as per the rules laid down by the Dental Council of India! For your information, we 'diagnose’, and 'treat’ diseases related to the Head and Neck region. Dentistry is already a speciality on it's own, because of it's vastness with respect to the teeth, surrounding structures and the craniofacial region. And oh, we also have 9 departments to specialize in, in India. In the States and everywhere else in the world, dentists are the highest paid. The next time you've a severe toothache, try visiting a General Physician for the same. You'll know why we're called doctors too :)

Yes, indeed. In Germany at least, I know a few who have done this, in order to specialize in maxillo-facial surgery. And, incidentally, they are then known as Herr/Frau Dr. Dr. The one I knew always insisted on his “double doctor” mode of address!
Yes, a dentist is a medical doctor. The dentist may have one of the two titles Doctor of Dentistry Surgery (DDS) or Doctor of Dental Medicine (DMD).
Why not?? They go through anatomy, physiology, surgical understanding of oral cavity especially the tooth. They diagnose & treat tooth problems.
No. If the person went to dental school and obtained a DDS, degree, a doctor of dental surgery, then no. If they earned the combined M.D./DDS, then yes, many have done that for oral surgery.

The degrees given in he US are DDS, Doctor of Dental Surgery, and DMD, Doctor of Dental Medicine. The degrees are essentially the same and differ in name only. MD means Doctor of Medicine. Doctor is a title. The proper descriptions would be dentist and physician.

Of course! The undergraduate hard sciences classes are the same. Chemistry, Physics, Statistics, Microbiology, Biology, etc. The dentist would need to attend Medical School to learn the human body in wellness and illness. Complete internship to have direct patient care experience, and a fellowship if desired a Specialty.

Multiple choice test for you. A DMD is a "DOCTOR of Dental Medicine" and a DDS is a "DOCTOR of Dental Surgery". Is a person with either of these degrees a: (A) Plumber ? (B) Secretary ? (C) DOCTOR ? (D) None of the Above
DDS = Doctor of Dental Surgery DMD = Doctor of Dental Medicine (I don’t know why the last two letters are switched - probably was originally in Latin or something)
Yes. DDS is means a Doctor of Dentistry, Dental School is as rigorous as Medical or Veterinary School. They have earned it!
Yes, Dentists are doctors . The correct terminology would be they are “ Doctor of Dental Medicine” “ DDM” or it’s equivalent in other areas of the world.
No
Yes they are. But they don’t get the respect that they deserve even though they are entitled to.
No, they are not MEDICAL doctors. They are doctors (because their degree is doctoral level) of dental medicine/surgery.
An MD is a doctor of medicine. A DDS is a doctor of dental surgery. Some people have combined them for a MD,DDS. These usually practice maxillofacial surgery.
I read somewhere: “You will understand the answer of ur question on the day when you will have tooth pain”
I have answered it here .Please check Adarsh Padiyar's answer to Can a dentist use the title "Dr." in India?
No, we are not physicians (MD) we are either a Doctor of Dental Surgery (DDS) or Doctor of Dental Medicine (DMD).

Of course s/he can. In fact, many of the basic science classes, such as gross anatomy, micro anatomy, microbiology, physiology, etc are common to both medical and dental schools. Depending on the student and the school, It’s quite possible for a dentist to pick up the remaining basic science classes needed and to take the clinical classes to graduate with a M.D. degree in a shortened time, say three years instead of four. A dual degree doctor would be quite desirable in some places.
Yes, a dentist is a doctor. So is anyone who has earned a PhD in any field. Remember Dr Indiana Jones?
Yes
